text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with grilled tuna with fresh
horseradish so I am a huge sushi fan and
what I like about sushi is the
simplicity fresh fish served with very
simple condiments so this is sort of
inspired by that alright let's get
rolling or as I should probably say
giddy up
so I came across this horseradish root
in a local market and I thought you know
what I love wasabi which is a type of
radish so here we go I wanted to keep
this very very basic so the base here
the delivery system for our grated
horseradish is going to be simply some
soy sauce with an equal part of seasoned
rice vinegar a little maybe quarter half
a teaspoon of sambal just to give it a
different kind of spiciness
so the horseradish is going to give us
one kind of heat all right in the sambal
sort of another type so once my base was
done I simply took a knife and trimmed
off sort of the bark all right that dark
outside of the horseradish root
I took my microplane grater and I shaved
fresh horseradish into that mixture and
how much I had no idea I just kept
shaving and shaving I wanted it really
intense
I wanted that soy and vinegar mixture to
just be completely permeated and
dominated by the fresh horseradish so
when I thought I had enough I stopped
and the last addition here
I took some very sweet cherry tomatoes
slice them thin and I added that to the
mixture I thought that would give it a
little bit of acidity a little bit more
sweetness and some visual appeal alright
so don't underestimate visual appeal all
right I'm gonna let that sit for about
20 minutes to sorta you know come
together while I grill my tuna I took a
very hot grill just lightly lightly
brush my tuna with oil and I grilled it
for about 3 minutes per side and no
that's not enough to cook it through but
I didn't want to cook it through
I wanted it pink in the middle of course
I got to give it my diamond shaped grill
marks you know just to show off and
we've done demos on that before you just
give it a little half turn and you got
grill marks just like on the magazine
covers
and as I watch this grill I thought to
myself this would be fantastic with
swordfish mahi-mahi what else pretty
much anything
salmon okay so don't ever only do stuff
like I show you all right three minutes
or so per side I was happy I was done I
took him off i spooned over that
beautifully simple yet exploding with
flavor soy rice vinegar horseradish
mixture you can see my beautiful
tomatoes and then to finish off I
thought hey let's grate over some more
fresh horseradish because it looks so
cool and it smelled so unbelievable and
I figured you just can't have too much
fresh horseradish and then last but not
least a little pinch of green onion for
some color for a little sharpness in the
final bite by the way you don't want a
great horse rash ahead of time because
if you leave it out in the air it
oxidizes and apparently turns bitter and
we don't want that who wants that okay
so great this is the last minute and
there you go that's a beautiful plate of
food and for a first time experiment
using fresh horseradish
I thought came out beautifully by the
way very interesting how horseradish
came to be named so you want to check
out the blog post to learn all about
that hey you never know when you're
going to end up on a taproot based
trivia show and could use this info so
you're welcome
so let me give this a taste oh yeah just
as I imagined if you like soy sauce with
wasabi in it you're probably going to
like this soy mixture with freshly
grated horseradish a very similar flavor
profile by the way please excuse me from
using the phrase flavor profile getting
a little overused these days so anyway
if you can find fresh horseradish I
really hope you give this recipe a try
all the ingredient amounts are on food
wishes calm as usual
and as always enjoy
